Award.AwardTitle: New, GK-12: Infusing System Design and Sensor Technology in Education (INSIGHT)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
New, GK-12: Infusing System Design and Sensor Technology in Education (INSIGHT)

This project integrates sensor technology with computing and information science in a standards-based science, technology, and engineering curricula. Project activities team GK-12 STEM Fellows with science, technology, and physical education teachers. Activities include both summer and academic year training in rural Kansas schools. In the summer, project staff provides fellows and teachers with training in hands-on, sensor-driven science, engineering, and technology development and appropriate pedagogical strategies. During the academic year, fellows support participating teachers in the classroom two times a week with content-specific sensor technology. The intellectual merit lies in the focus on the technology and engineering aspects of STEM education and on the use of sensors, computing, and information technology as the enabling element to facilitate hands-on technology and engineering education in areas related to telemedicine and precision agriculture.

Broader impacts include the establishment of sensor, computing, and information technology as a foundational high school skill by accelerating the integration of sensor technology content into Kansas high school science and technology classes.
The curriculum is aligned with state curriculum standards. The project is innovative because it will enhance the usefulness, practicality, and relevance of sensor technology education by linking research for fellows to high school science and technology curriculum, and provide communication and research opportunities in sensor technology for doctoral students in engineering. This project encourages participation in engineering and technology from an even wider, more diverse group of students from rural Kansas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Kansas State University (KSU) National Science Foundation (NSF) GK-12 Program Infusing System Design and Sensor Technology in Education (INSIGHT) was part of an interdisciplinary program that teamed researchers with rural communities to study two aspects impacting rural life: agriculture and cyber-physical systems. The primary focus of this project was to enhance the communication and team building skills of a diverse group of GK-12 STEM Fellows by infusing software design and sensors into K-12 classrooms. Specifically, we developed software and training modules for a wide range of sensors and systems, recruited and paired a diverse group of Graduate STEM Fellows with STEM teachers from the upper elementary through high school level, conducted an intense two-week summer institute each summer to train the fellows and teachers, and supported the ongoing training and fellow/student/teacher interaction and development during the academic year. One novel aspect of our program was to stagger the recruitment of fellows and teachers so that veteran fellows and teachers could provide valuable insight and feedback to the incoming fellows/teachers. GK-12 STEM Fellows worked with classroom teachers to incorporate their research expertise into the ongoing standards-based curriculum with the goal to enhance the usefulness, practicality, and relevance of sensor, computing and information technology through scientific, hands-on activities. This created a unique community of learning, teaching, and support between higher and K-12 education participants from rural and Hispanic backgrounds. The interdisciplinary atmosphere enhanced the GK-12 STEM Fellows’ confidence to communicate effectively and provide leadership. The fellows’ enthusiasm towards their research stimulated interest and inspired students to consider careers in STEM disciplines. Since 2013, we have seen a steady increase in the number of students enrolling in Computer Science from 93 to 149, with significantly more diversity.

A total of 25 GK-12 STEM Fellows participated in the program and worked with 45 in-service K-12 teachers to inspire a new generation of over 4,500 K-12 students across the state of Kansas in rural and high needs urban areas. After their participation, the GK-12 Fellows acknowledged the value of continued involvement with K-12 classrooms.

The following are a few quotes from the participating STEM teachers:

  • “This has been such a wonderful program and brought things into my classroom I would never have done. I was able to talk with my students about the engineering behind weather instruments, an activity I do every year, but with more information. It has inspired my students and increased their curiosity about many things.”
  • “[T]he activity Emily shared with my kids went fantastic. She did an outstanding job and the kids really enjoyed it. The activity was one I could never have done myself. Her knowledge and expertise was what made the activity possible. She was prepared and presented it with confidence. It was a great day.”
  • “On Friday, Jed and I presented a lesson with the physics students using photogate sensors in combination with rockets to determine trajectory characteristics such as theoretical range and max altitude. The students were all engaged and enjoyed the lesson. The better technology of a photogate sensor rather than a hand-held stopwatch further enhanced the lesson and provided for better data. It was a successful lesson and I am planning on using it in future years.”
  • “I have a deeper understanding of the leg work that must go into even the smallest of programming!
